author: sfgate.com
title: Daily Briefing, Oct. 1
text:
Number of the day 
200,000 
That’s the number of jobs U.S. companies added in September, payroll firm ADP said Wednesday. The job growth was up from 186,000 in August, a figure that was revised down 4,000 from the initial estimate.
D’oh 
Costco officials said Wednesday that customers who ordered online photos between June 2014 and July 2015 may be at risk after the company’s site was hacked. The company said e-mail addresses, physical addresses, passwords and some credit card numbers were compromised, and Costco is encouraging customers to change their passwords for all online accounts.
Huh? 
Whole Foods will stop selling products made using a prison labor program after a protest at one of its stores in Texas, the Associated Press reported. Whole Foods has sold tilapia, trout and goat cheese produced through a Colorado inmate program at some stores since at least 2011. Those products should be out of its stores by April, if not sooner. A Whole Foods spokesman said the company decided to end the practice because some customers were uncomfortable with it.
The Daily Briefing is compiled from San Francisco Chronicle staff and news services. See more items and links at www.sfgate.com . Twitter: @techchronicle
